Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned a lot about current areas of research in psychology, and the methods used to gain new insight into the workings of the brain.

How to conduct psych experiments

Understanding cognitive functioning
A very broad overview of psychology. As most of psychology is, it is very descriptive rather than mechanistic, which is probably unavoidable.
a general survey of psychology (the field)
This course was just a broad overview of psychology, but I feel like it forced us to really make us think about the deeper workings of our mind and how that influences our daily lives.
This course provided an overview of a wide array of topics in the massive field of psychology. Even still, we managed to go into a reasonably deep level of detail on many of these.
-basic theories of psychology
I feel as if I learned all of the basic psychological concepts.
I have a good understanding of a variety of topics relevant in psychology.
Gained an array of knowledge concerning psychological concepts.

Because of this class, I now want to major in psychology. The class has taught me so much valuable lessons that are so applicable in daily life; it's astonishing how differently I see daily life now. I also learned how to apply concepts we learned to current events through the reading responses, and in general learn to extend the lecture material to the bigger picture.
I developed an awareness of many topics in psychology and an appreciation for the general methods of study used in the field to conduct research.

In this course, we learn a basic overview of psychology. There is a mixture of dry textbook readings and popular literature, which I generally enjoyed. The material is very interesting and Bloom is the best lecturer I've ever had.
Introduction to Psychology. IT WAS AN AMAZING CLASS.
Very interesting lectures and I learned lots of things about myself and how my brain works.

A broad understand of the main psychological principles: I feel that I know have a better understanding of how my mind might work, how to be happy, why I'm sad, and how to make up and break up with people!
I learned so much about so many aspects of every day life, thought etc. New perspectives, why people act the way they do, etc.
From sleep to attraction to neuroscience to Freud, this class covered everything.
Good survey course in psych.
I learned so much, it cannot really be summarized here. But this is a great overview of psychology that sparked a further interest in this field.

This class was INCREDIBLY informative about life and human nature through the lens of psychology. An amazing introduction to psychology. Learned many things about myself and others than I now can use to understand the people and world around me.
I learned a lot about the breadth of psychology.
The course is a very good introduction to psychology, covering most of the GREAT Psych topics. It is broad but also kind of specific. it is really fun!
Learned a lot about psych, wonderful course.
basic info about field of psychology
Gained a lot of knowledge about the basics of psychology.  The course was interesting and engaging.

I gained an insight into the psychological process and what motivates people's behaviors. On top of this, I received an overview of the history of psychology and famous theories that went along with it.
I developed the introductory skills in analyzing psychology, as well as honed my reasoning and writing skills
I learned the basics of the field of psychology and the main experiments that contributed to the topic and where the field is heading towards in modern days.
I learned a wide variety of info about psychology. While nothing was particular in-depth, the course offered a wide breadth of information that is applicable to my daily life.
good intro psyche class.
I learned an umbrella of the many aspects of psychology.

This class taught exactly what it said it would.  The class covered the dimensions of the mind and how science has come to these realizations through experimentation and observation.  The class was easy to follow and each lecture/topic followed a simple pattern (what people thought a long time ago -> what we know now -> how we used science to figure all of it out).  These steps made it easy for me (a STEM major) to understand the concepts.  I was worried the class would be closer to astrology than astronomy, but that wasn't the case at all. 
I had a great time

I learned basic concepts of psychology such as the function of parts of the brain, different mental disorders, morality, attraction, conditioning, etc. I came out of the course being able to notice these concepts in real life, which felt rewarding.
I learned a bit about psychology. It was not too in depth which made it hard to fully grasp but hey, its an intro psych course

I gained a solid background in the field of psychology, learning several historical and current approaches and an overview of subjects such as learning, development, social psychology, and mental disorders.
I learned a significant amount about the field.
I learned about a variety of topics including emotion, memory, morality, and evolutionary psychology. I gained a basic understanding of a range of areas of modern psychology.
I learned some very cool facts about psych - it's mad out there.
I learned a lot of introductory psychology on a very wide variety of topics.
general knowledge about the field of psychology
This course was technically a very cursory and introductory look at psychology, but I genuinely feel like I can understand others and my own behavior better having taken this course
I learned a lot of interesting concepts in psychology that inspired me to pursue it further.
I received a pretty across the board introduction into all things psych.
I learned a lot about psychology
I learned some really cool psychology concepts and history. I'm excited to apply the insights from the course to real life!

I learned an incredible amount of information this semester through this course! Every few days covered a different topic within the field of psychology, from mental illness to morality to behavioral psychology to social psychology to different elements of personality and emotion. This course is an amazing sampling of all of the major themes in psychology, and every lecture is full of information that always left me feeling fascinated and like I truly learned something interesting and new. I think this course did a great job of exposing students to the breadth and depth of psychology, and it really served to introduce us to all that psychology has to offer. There was a major emphasis of taking the information we learned and applying it to situations in our personal lives or our interactions with the rest of society. I really felt like I left the class with a better understanding of myself, others around me, and society as a whole.
Very good introduction to all the major topics in psych. Prof bloom is a really good lecturer so class was always Super engaging
I learned a bit about major fields of psychological study, and a bit about the major questions that can be addressed using psychology.

I learned a lot about the history of psychology and psychological philosophy. I do wish that we had gone more into the empirics on psychology -- specific studies that came to specific conclusions, rather than having everything dictated to us as fact or abstract philosophy (from what I've heard, this is more of a Prof. Bloom thing than other professors, but if you're more into the philosophical side, Bloom is perfect for you). Professor Bloom is an invigorating, dynamic lecturer who, while his lectures sometimes seem a little rambly and it's hard to know exactly what to take notes on, is nonetheless incredibly engaging to listen to.
synthesizing information through reading response, introductory psychology and behavioral economics
Very broad yet in-depth introduction to the field of psychology
I gained insight into how the mind works and how to study it.
This was entirely new material, so every day provided a new insight!
Foundational concepts in psychology and critical figures/experiments that have created the modern psychology that we have today.
I learned the basics of every main field of psychology, and I have frequently been able to apply what I have learned to my daily life.
I realized I am very interested in psychology and may consider this to be my major.
The class offered a broad overview of many psychology topics.
A broad understanding of the human mind
Take this class for sure. Bloom was absolutely incredible.
I learned a lot of factual stuff
I think I got a full and complete introductory view of human behavior and psychology.
I learned the basic fields of psychology and where insights in these fields come from.
I gained a thorough overview of the different fields and focuses of psychology, the different approaches to them, and the questions that are still open to research.
A broad and fascinating introduction to the areas of psychology
Good survey course where you learn a lot across many different categories.

A brief, broad introduction to psychology. Doesn't go into too specific an exploration into each field, but Professor Bloom teases out the interesting and wild possibilities of each through great case studies.
General knowledge of psychological concepts, theories, and experiments that provide a good base for future study in psychology and related fields.
I am now more knowledgeable on the human brain as a whole and of the unknowns about psychology.
I learned more general things about psychology and about the mysteries that still puzzle psychologists to this day.

I learned some basic functions of the brain, why we dream, love, trust. Generally, I learned why we do the things we do and why we think the way we think. Lastly, I learned scientific ways we can test and observe these psychological phenomena.
Taught me how to effectively understand the enigmas of my mind to increase my thinking abilities.
How to apply psych in the real world.

You learn to connect concepts between the range of topics within the class as well as across class disciplines and current events. 
You learn to write concisely and to identify and articulate psychological analyses. 
In addition, the class is set up to impart diligence and time-management skills onto the students. 
Overall, you develop the skill of intellectual flexibility.

I have learned so much from this course. I have learned about mental illness, morality, the origins of creationism, Freud, Skinner, the scientific method, the nature of evil, love, rationality, drug addiction... the list goes on. This course has taught me more about life and human behavior than any other course at Yale. I feel extremely blessed to have been able to take it. My favorite course at Yale hands down.
Tons

Intro psych gives a good overview of the different disciplines of psychology, some of the key experiments that laid the foundation for modern theories, and a bit about research methods. Contemporary TED talks and journal articles added thought-provoking perspectives to the main principles touched upon in lecture and readings.
I learned a wide range of material about the basics of psychology. It demonstrated to me a lot of why humans behave the way we do.
I learned about basic concepts and experiments in psychology, as well as an overview of the history of psychology.

I learned a lot of fundamental psychology concepts, as well as various methods often used in psychology research. Additionally, I learned a lot of interesting and seemingly random facts that supplemented the course content and kept lectures engaging. Through this course, I gained a better understanding of humans and how we think, although I continue to be intrigued by all the things we don't yet know.

I learned so much in this course---the various types of psychology scientists' study and the experiments that they conduct to test their theories. We learned about Cognitive Psych, Behavioral and Skinner, Social Psychology--Freud, Milgram etc. Professor Bloom taught his lectures by themes and each lecture was dedicated to that theme --love, attraction, behavior, sleep etc.
As I've never taken a psychology course before, the class was an excellent introduction to the subject, going into the different branches of psychology.
You learn a lot of the basics of psychology, as well as many interesting facts, that span over a variety of topics (research methods, morality, development, etc.)
I learned a lot about the human brain and function.

As the first psychology course I have ever taken, the class taught me a great amount about the field as a whole. The course is intentionally designed to provide an overview rather than diving deeply into any particular area, so the information was not particularly revelatory, but it provided an excellent foundation to take later psychology classes.
I learned so many interesting facts about our psychology-- the most applicable being love/attraction, cognitive dissonance, and memory
I learned a lot of surface level details about the major topics in psychology.
A general background in psychology.
Intro to Psych was a good overview introduction to the fascinating subject of psychology.

I learned the basics behind understanding psychology which was very interesting because it often changed the way I thought about life and decision making. It is great to take Credit/D because you learn a lot from the lectures without the pressure!
I learned about multiple areas of psychology
I love this course and Professor Bloom really makes the material come to life. I learned a lot about a wide variety of psychology and loved it.
Beyond learnings tons about psychology experiments, principles, etc., I was really pushed to give thorough reading responses, improve my studying habits, and more.

I had never taken a psych course and this was a really fantastic overview of some common psych topic. The lessons provide a huge range and I really feel like I have learned stuff that I will remember.

I was able to gain a large breadth of understanding in a vareity of pyschological topics from behavorial, clinical and social pyschology. I gained an appreciation of some of the history and evolution of fields in psychology.
Good basic overview of psychology: conditioning, sleep, love, religion, etc.

I learned about the foundations of psychology. The course gave me a broad overview of every topic of psychology, so that if I were to study psych in the future I would understand the different areas of the subject matter.
Better understanding of how people learn, adapt, judge.
I learnt surprising and interesting things about behavior and also causes of certain behaviors. I was able to evaluate every day behavior based on psychology which i thought was pretty cool.
About basic topics in psychology

I learned about the primary fields of psychology: their history, proponents/detractors, theories, and major discoveries. I developed the ability to understand new scientific breakthrough in psychology as well as to evaluate fundamental questions about human nature and behavior that psychology research seeks to answer.

The relatively heavy reading load, coupled with my other time demanding classes, allowed me to develop a routine that worked for me. My time management skills were improved. I also developed many perspectives about those around me which helped me in my social relationships.

I didn't learn a whole lot in this course. We just kind of learned some random psych facts that you hear about from time to time in online articles. I took intro to cog sci, which is where we actually read papers about where these kinds of statistics come from instead of just being blindly told them.
I received an overview of the field of psychology, and got a taste of its various branches (such as developmental psychology, social psychology, and clinical psychology).
This course has helped me understand the complex components of my personality. Having learnt about the spotlight effect, I walk carefree now without feeling as though I am being watched.
This class gave a good overview of different branches of psychology. I developed skills to apply concepts from the readings and lectures into more real-life situations.
A introduction to cool facts about psychology.
I learned a lot in the course surrounding various aspects of psychology as it is such as huge and growing field.
I learned about how the mind works!
I learned how to effectively take notes and read consistently for class.
I discovered a great interest in Psychology during this course.

I gained a comprehensive knowledge of fundamental psych concepts: all the fascinating facts about relationships, your brain, childhood, learning, etc. that you wonder about all your life and are suddenly explained so clearly!
insight across many aspects of psychology
I gained a lot of foundational knowledge about psychology; the material we covered was always interesting.
Introductory psych stuff. Pretty standard I think.

The course covers a lot--everything from sleep and dreams to the brain as the mind and personality disorders. You learn a lot about how humans behave and why, and it's a great introduction to understanding the psychological basis of human actions and thinking.
Professor Bloom is a great lecturer who clearly spent time planning each lecture.
I learned about the complex the topics in psychology and how they pertain to everyday life.
A basic understanding of psychology as a subject and the basic tools to approach it with.
I learned about the various fields of psychology, the history of psychology, and some of the basic psychological concepts.

This class was a great introduction to a wide variety of topics in psychology. The guest lectures covered topics like love, neurobio, and drugs. Throughout the course we talked about clinical psychology, intelligence, biases, etc. It is interesting information that always seems to come up later in conversations and interactions with others.
Overview of psychology
A comprehensive knowledge of psychology and overall the way our minds work.

This course taught the basics of psychology. This introductory knowledge to psychology was very interesting and has given me an insight to why people are the way that they are - especially with emotions, behaviors, and thoughts.
I learned many key experiments and topics in psychology.
I developed a greater knowledge of the history of psychology as well as the different schools of thought

I gained insight into the workings of the human mind and how things we often fail to perceive play a huge role in our every day decision and experiences. It was very interesting to learn about the different areas of psychology and how they interact amongst themselves as well as with other disciplines. Through the reading responses, I learnt how to apply this learning and see things through a different lens.
Truly my favorite course this semester! I learned that I love psychology through this course, as well as how to combine personal thought, research, and practice through reading responses.

I got a basic understanding of psychology. I've always wanted to take an intro course and this was a great class for that. I learned a ton about the human brain, emotions, social behavior, etc. I also learned a lot of skills that I can apply to my daily life, to better understand why I and others think and act the way we do.
I surveyed most psych related fields and retaught myself how to approach thinking about thinking.
I have definitely found new ways to consider and understand the human brain and its functions.
I felt like I learned how to question my own perception of common sense.

I now have a fairly broad (but not too deep) understanding of the field of psychology. In general, I am now much more likely to consider the reasons behind why we act the way we do, and how this behavior formed. Some of the topics I most enjoyed included nature vs. nurture, the origins of morality, and sleep(!).

As a history major, I have never been exposed to psychology outside of popular culture. As such, it was a very rewarding experience learning so much about psychology in this course. It is a very interesting field.

Intro Psych is a great survey introductory psych course. The readings are very manageable, you learn about various topics such as intelligence, personality, emotion, dreams, laughter, etc., and in doing the weekly reading responses I developed the ability to see how psych applies to the real world.

This course provided a comprehensive introduction to the field of psychology.   Because there are so many subtopics within psychology, this course is definitely a broad overview.  Some of the topics we covered included Freuds psychodynamic theory, Skinners behaviorism, child development, language, memory, emotions, religion, and morality.  In other words, this course uses psychology to answer some of the most basic things about humans, such as our thoughts, behaviors, and actions (or why we are the way that we are).  After taking this course, I now know that there are reasons or patterns for everything that we do, and that those reasons and patterns are studied within psychology.
everyday social, behavioral, and cognitive awareness
Strengths: Professor Bloom is an engaging lecturer -- class always went by quickly, and I felt like I was learning a lot of interesting things. The workload is manageable, and exams were fair

Weaknesses: Reading responses are worth too much

Strength: Great, funny professor
Test design does lead to long term retention.

The course with Bloom is extraordinarily engaging in lecture and has excellent readings which really expand understanding of different topics. The workload is appropriate to the topic (intro psych) and the exams seemed very fair to me.

The biggest weakness is the reading responses. They are supposed to be 500-600 words, but the topics given would often require a lot of padding to get to that point. Sometimes you could answer in about 200 words and be like, "Well shoot-- guess I need to write some meaningless sentences."

The subject matter this semester was too broad -- Professor Bloom tried to cover too much of the history of psychology and didn't go deep enough on the concepts. It was very hard to understand a lot of the concepts because we got very vague explanations. Professor Bloom, however, is an amazing and engaging lecturer. The readings were distributed unequally so some weeks I would spend a solid 6 hours on them and other weeks I would spend only one hour, which made this course hard to plan around in terms of time commitment.
Strengths of the course include its content and professor. Weaknesses are the tests and reading responses (not enough chances to get grades)

The structure of the course made it very easy to connect concepts. Also, the lecture didn't exclusively cover the readings, so I feel like I was able to learn more. However, I disliked the reading responses because they're graded out of three, there's only 10, they're worth 35% of our grade, and if you make a mistake you get bumped down to a 2, which is a 66%/D. The reading responses weren't difficult themselves but they made it feel like it was hard to do well in the course.
Strength - Prof Bloom was a great lecturer

Strengths: the content was delivered in a very organized and engaging way. 

Weaknesses: the test was very specific; I go to all the lectures and do the reading assignments but wasnt able to recall some of the contents on the test

The material in this course is interesting and well taught. I really enjoyed the selection of readings from outside the Noba textbook, although the ones within it were a bit dry and laden with obscure terminology. The lectures were very good, and the reading responses were usually interesting and enjoyable.

My one complaint would be that the exams often seemed to be valuing raw memorization over actual understanding. While I understand that a multiple-choice test may be the only feasible option for such a large class, I still think that rote memorization of overly-specific details does not constitute learning and thus should not be required.
-weaknesses: grading homework out of 3

Weaknesses: the reading responses were only out of 3 points, so it was hard to get a good grade on those even if you worked really hard. The fact that we had to spend five hours on experiments that did not add anything to our final grade, but could only hurt us. There should've been a participation grade for that. The TAs were pretty unhelpful- I was told that they were not allowed to give us feedback. I don't really understand the point of having a TA that isn't allowed to help me.

Strengths: Professor Bloom.

Sometimes there were a LOT of readings assigned for one week, and then little to no readings assigned for the next.  I understand that some topics have more material/coverage, but readings for all topics would give more depth to them.

Strengths: Paul Bloom is both very interesting and passionate. You will learn a lot while being engaged in every single lecture 

Weaknesses: The reading responses do not add much value to the class other than creating a rushed homework assignment every weekend--they are busy work. The weight placed on the 2 exams also create extreme stress; would be much better suited to have some of the grade be based upon our experimental participation
Overall, the class was fantastic. The only thing is that some major topics in psychology were not covered in the course, but that might be because of the time limit.

Professor Bloom is a first-rate lecturerhe's incredibly engaging, and the questions he poses are thought-provoking.  The exams in the course were a poor representation of the important takeaways of the material we learned, but the course is nonetheless worthwhile because of how strong Professor Bloom's lectures are.

The biggest weakness was the reading responses. For some reason, they are out of 3 points, so if you have one little thing wrong, you're suddenly down to a D+! They were also graded pretty harshly. I also think that 600 words is kind of a lot, I could usually state my ideas in 300-400 and had to just add fluff to make it to 600. The biggest strength is Paul Bloom. He is an excellent professor! Coming to lecture was actually fun, and it was the class I looked forward to most every week!

Paul Bloom is an absolutely AMAZING professor, I miss the class already. I really really really enjoyed the lectures, guest lectures, and even writing reading responses. I think sometimes the reading response requirements were a bit unclear.
The lectures are wonderful, it would be nice if there were sections so we can discuss some of the topics in smaller groups.
Incredible lectures, and the reading responses were always relevant. No improvements needed!

Lectures for this course are straight up entertaining. Loved it.

Assignments are not overwhelming but they do help you learn and reflect (reading responses).

The course is run well and Prof Bloom is a wonderful lecturer and very responsive to emails. The only drawback was the grading system of the Reading Responses. Prof Bloom has said he will fix it for next time he teaches the course, but they were by far the biggest minus of the class.
Strengths: engaging lectures, broad exploration of many topics
Solid class.

Strength: The professor, the readings, the teaching fellows

Weaknesses: ????
All strength. Only weakness was that reading responses were graded out of 3 so if you lost a point (very common for a "great" response, 3s very rare), your average was literally a 66%. YIKES

The grading of the reading responses makes it far too hard to get a good grade. If you don't complete a response perfectly then you get a 2/3, so you either get a perfect score of you fail the response. 

The review sessions were also a bit lackluster. There was very little review information available.
No weaknesses.

Strengths: Paul Bloom, interesting topics

Weaknesses: fast pace
Overall the lecture and readings were of a very high quality, my main frustration was the homework being graded out of 3 as it lead to slightly draconian grading of small mistakes.

I think the lectures are very informative, entertaining and helpful. The only gripe I have with the class is the grading system. I feel as though there is too much weight on the two exams and that the point distribution could be spread out a bit better.

I was a big fan of the reading responses and having two independent exams without a final - that way, more assignments were spread out to help count for the final grade. However, I found the exams to be unnecessarily difficult in terms of asking ambiguous questions.

The strengths of this course is the lectures that were very interesting coupled with the readings which complimented the course pretty well. The weakness that I found with this class were the reviews sessions given by the T.As which did not seem that helpful. Also the reading responses being rated on a 1-3 scale seemed a bit harsh as any minor mistake leads to a 66%/100%

Strengths: great lecturer, little reading. Weaknesses: reading responses were graded out of the 3 points, so if you got one minor thing wrong, you were at a D. This system needs fixing - just grade them out of 10!
the grading of the reading responses needs to be changed. it was unfair to both the graders and the students. I think the reading responses should be more open ended as well.
The two tests were ridiculously hard
I did not complete enough work due to an illness.  I would complete all of my work.

Bloom is a fantastic lecturer. Although there was a lot of overlap with Intro Cognitive Science, Bloom found ways to keep the material engaging and exciting. Very reasonable workload, and the exams were a good balance of difficulty, although maybe overly detailed-oriented, but nothing unmanageable.

Strengths: The lectures are engaging and easy to follow.  The TFs answer questions promptly if there are any issues.  Paul Bloom seems to really want to teach the course and his enthusiasm is infectious.
Weaknesses: I was never really sure how I was actually doing in the course.  It was hard to compare my performance over time or to others.  Feedback was slight; limited to a single sentence or two for every reading response and the marks on the midterm exam.  This could be improved by maybe a quiz or two.  I tend to think that most college courses should have more evaluation, though I realize that this creates more work for everyone and less time for teaching.  A second practice midterm might also be good.

The lectures are very entertaining, with fun video clips and Dr. Bloom's engaging teaching style. The information is extremely interesting, and I often found myself noticing and applying concepts we had learned from the course in real life scenarios. However, the grading on the reading responses was very specific (only one point off gives one a grade of 66%) and I often felt like the tests were focused on small details from the TED talks, articles, or readings rather than the psychology material itself. It was sometimes hard to know what information was pertinent. Overall, this was definitely one of the most interesting and engaging courses I have taken, and I always looked forward to lecture.

This was a very interesting course, but I hated the textbook. Not only was it poorly written, it also did not cover the same material as the course. Also the exams were a tad bit unfair due to the fact that 95% of the material came directly from the readings and covered unimportant facts that would need to be memorized rather than main ideas and concepts. For an intro psych class there should be less of a need to recall one tiny piece of information from a reading that you did literally three months prior to the exam. I also hated the mandatory research participation component. It did not teach me anything and was a complete waste of my time.

Very good overall. The course moves quickly, which keeps things interesting but means that some topics get very little attention (all of "attraction" was covered in one lecture). I don't have any advice for improvement, however.
I feel like this class is marketed as an intro level class, however, with significant time commitment and lack of clarity on certain responses, I felt a little lost at times.

The lectures were always enjoyable and the material was interesting. I would have preferred if the exams required less memorization and more deep understanding (like with an essay), but I know that this is difficult with such a big lecture course.
I did not like the 3 point grading system on the weekly reading responses. I found some weeks rather difficult and upset by subtle confusions and errors in referencing things led to receiving 2/3.

Strengths: Engaging lectures, interesting course material, great professor and guest lecturers 

Weaknesses: It goes by really fast, so it's hard to keep up. Also, I feel like I forgot the majority of what I learned after the exam. There are a lot of readings, and the reading responses are graded harshly.

Professor Bloom is a great lecturer! I sometimes wished we would stay on a topic for more days, but st the same time i understand why we only did one topic per day because we got to get through more material

The lectures and topics we went over were great, but the grading was unfair. Choosing to grade the responses out of 3 was really punishing and a very small mistake could add up and impact your grade a lot

The lectures for this course with Paul Bloom are extremely engaging and informative. It is also good that the course does not have section because the readings are straightforward and it would feel unnecessary.
The material is very interesting.  The readings are numerous and lengthy.  The required experimental participation is also not as entertaining as could be but is not that bad of a time commitment.
This course showed the scope of the field of psychology. The class was very interesting and engaging.

strengths: paul bloom is such a great and exceptional and at times hilarious (!!) lecturer. the classes flew by and almost never checked the time (except for one lecture near the end). oh and also bloom gives the BEST and most wholesome and personal introductions to guest speakers. 
weaknesses: exams are really specific and based more on terms/memorization! sad! i loved the course but i honestly felt the exams didn't meaningfully test my understanding of topics and ability to apply them. the only major grades are your midterm and final and i felt these didn't give me the chance to illustrate my grasp of the course. also the milgram lecture was the only one that was painfully boring to sit through.
The reading responses didn't feel too tied in with the course material sometimes.
Professor Bloom is AMAZING! He is an outstanding lecturer and he definitely captivates and engages the audience.

Every single lecture was full of so much interesting information that could actually be applied to our own lives and the ways that we interact with the rest of society. One of the strengths is how applicable and fascinating all of the information is; I never felt a moment where I wasn't completely engaged and interested in what was being discussed. Professor Bloom also made sure to post all of the slides on Canvas so we could go back and review some of the key points and examples presented in the class. This course was definitely my favorite course that I took this semester, and I will really miss it!
The guest lecturers are a strong point of the course (not because Professor Bloom is a bad lecturer but because they are so knowledgeable about the topics that they lecture in).

Blooms lectures are amazing and engaging  the only thing I didnt enjoy about the class was the grading scheme centered around reading responses scored out of 3, which made it easy to lose significant points if you messed up on one.

Prof bloom as a lecturer is definitely a strength.  
The course is very comprehensive so we don't learn too much detail but I think the balance struck at the moment with broad learning and detailed learning is really good. The reading responses can be Super interesting but sometimes t just feels like busy work.

Like any survey course, we flew through material at a more superficial level than I would have liked, but there's no other way to handle so much information. TAs and Professor Bloom were always available for questions or further information.

Strengths: 
    Professor Bloom is an incredible lecturer.
    The course is organized well overall.

Weaknesses: 
    The structure of each individual lecture doesn't leave room for a lot of studies/data.
    The textbook used this term was objectively pretty bad.
    The tests are incredibly specific and on minute details barely discussed in class, while foregoing testing the material tested. If you take this class with Bloom, be forewarned that his tests aren't 'hard' in the traditional sense, but rather choose to focus on very different aspects of the course than his lectures/the readings do.

The reading responses could be a bit excessive, but ultimately they did contribute to my learning for the exams. I would have preferred if they were graded out of 10 rather than out of 3 so students wouldn't risk a 66% with one mistake.
Course was well taught
Feedback was delayed for the reading responses but the course material was engaging.
Too much emphasis on reading and not enough on analysis

The lectures were fascinating and the readings were relevant.  The weekly reading responses were very helpful for learning and understanding the material. The reading responses should be out of at least ten points, though, so that there are more ways to distinguish between good and average responses.

Paul Bloom is a great lecturer so the class is fun to take, but the material itself often just takes the form of learning complicated names for very intuitive concepts. The material sometimes seems a bit nebulous, and like a watered-down version of a philosophy class.

The class was overall fabulous. I would say that making the homework reading more evenly distributed each day would lighten the load on a lot of weeks and make it so that we have fewer stretches where there was no homework.
I think there is a lot of information, due to the expansive field of psychology, and the course would be better offered with more frequent tests.
The reading responses shouldnt be graded out of 3

This course had very engaging lectures. Reading responses could have had more of a scale for grading. TA's were lovely. Exams seemed mismatched to course at times. Overall decrease in amount of reading by about 10% to 20% would be helpful to keep up.
I adored this course. Paul Bloom is an excellent lecturer, and I found the readings very interesting and enjoyed writing most of my reading responses.

The strengths were the lectures, which were very engaging, and included lots of modern references, interesting examples, and live demonstrations. I also liked the guest lecture system. One weakness was the grading system of the reading responses, which were out of 3 but would have worked better out of 10. I also found some of the prompts to be a little unclear, and would have appreciated a little more guidance on what the earlier prompts wanted (the open ended news article analysis questions were a good feature though). Using a free online textbook was incredibly helpful, but I would also appreciate if we switched to a more interesting textbook.

Strengths: Professor, syllabus 
Could be improved by making reading responses out of 10
Paul Bloom is a great lecturer (albeit a little disorganized). Exams were not really testing material we learned.
Paul Bloom is an amazing lecturer and I really feel that I learned a lot from him. Readings ad reading responses were a struggle sometimes, especially because there is no detailed feedback.

There were only strengths in this course. It was taught very well even for being a lecture. Not only was I engaged all of the time in the material that was being taught, I also learned to love and retain most of what was spoken about during lecture which made it easier when studying for the final.
Lecture was wonderful. The readings were interesting and related to the lecture and I enjoyed spending time studying the material.
The course only had strengths as a whole. Paul Bloom managed to engage 200+ students with every lecture he gave.
Overall a well designed course with an amazing professor. It could be improved by changing the required experimental participation credits from 5 credits to 3. 5 was a lot, and it took a lot of time.
It will never be as good now that Paul Bloom is done teaching it. He was incredible and he mastered the art of the introduction to his guest speakers.
It was engaging.

The weekly reading response grading scale was lamentably skewed: 33% (F), 66% (D), or 100% (A). For the amount of work students put into each writing piece, anything below a 3/3 invalidated that, when it may have deserved a B or even C rather than a D, for example. 

The feedback was ambiguous, often not explaining what could have improved a response from a 2/3 to a 3/3. While the grade itself was unchangeable, at times I wanted to understand what conceptual understanding I had lacked to communicate that weakened my response.

Strengths: most everything. Amazing lectures, amazing professor, use of funny videos, use of guest lecturers, fair grading, fair tests.
Weaknesses: there is no mandatory section to attend and TAs have such different office hours/ I felt like this discouraged me from engage even deeper in a course that fascinates me. Furthermore, if there was a mandatory section to attend, I would have been able to get to know not only my TA but my peers more. This is too interesting of a class to not have discussion sections for.
I thought that the professor went too quickly through the presentations; it was very hard sometimes to keep up with the note-taking.

Some strengths are a good variety of topics and engaging lectures. I appreciated that the readings didn't feel excessive or waste time; they seemed to be chosen thoughtfully to provide new supplementary perspectives on the material and encourage us to think critically. I think it could be improved by perhaps some expectation of synthesis or further investigation into a certain area, such as a paper assignment or related project; it helps students to have more grades, and requires a bit more thought than the weekly reading responses alone.

The strengths are that the material was engaging and the homework load is not too heavy. However, the downside is that there is a lot of material which covers many topics and can be difficult to synthesize.

This is a very engaging course and I appreciate that the textbook online. 

I think it would be helpful for TAs to hold a weekly optional section to review concepts. Also, some of the guest lecturers were not great, so it would be better if there were fewer of them.

Professor Bloom is an absolutely incredible lecturer, and he keeps every class interesting. The course material itself is varied and supplemented with lots of interesting information, and I was always engaged during class. I also felt that the weekly reading responses were always thought-provoking and interesting questions, and they always felt manageable. I do wish there had been more opportunity for interaction with the teaching fellows - I know my teaching fellow held office hours, but I never felt like I needed to go. I would have loved to learn more about the work that each of the teaching fellows is doing themselves in the field, whether through a mini-lecture or just a short bio.

Strengths: Professor Bloom is the best teacher I have ever had. He is so brilliant and makes the course so exciting. Every single lecture was amazing. I think that the course is tough and a lot of work but very fair and worth it. 

Weaknesses: I understand being involved in experiments in an intro psych course but there were not very many experiments to participate in at least for athletes because many of the times conflicted with practice etc.
The professor is an excellent lecturer who makes the subject incredibly interesting. The course covers great topics.

Strengths: Interesting, engaging, not very difficult to comprehend
Weaknesses: The readings were distributed very unevenly. Sometimes you'd have three readings in a week, others you'd have seven readings due by the next class, so it was really hard to fit it in with my schedule.

Paul Bloom was an awesome lecturer. Most of my issues are with the structure of PSYC 110 itself. One of my biggest problems is with the PSYC points requirement. If youre under 18, you cant just go mindlessly sit in someones lab and be a test subject for the points, you have to write essays which seem like a drastic addition in work just by nature of your birthdate. That was the most annoying thing. Smaller, but still annoyingwhat his tests were going to cover were honestly ambiguous to me and so I would spend a lot of time studying things and be somewhat stupefied by a few terms on the tests.
The course is fun but could be more structured.

I think that the overall structure and content of the class was wonderful. Lectures were highly informative, and the reading responses allowed me to more deeply consider what had been discussed that week. My only complaint would be that while I greatly appreciated the lack of a discussion section for the sake of my schedule, it might have been helpful to have a space to talk about some of the concepts with other students--maybe an optional discussion section every now and then.
I think the reading responses should be graded out of 10 instead of 3.

Strengths: Bloom is an engaging lecturer, content is straightforward if you take the time to study
Weaknesses: soooooo much reading and the exams test the readings-- this class emphasizes memorization and there's so much material to memorize. The material isn't difficult to grasp, but the sheer amount of it makes it overwhelming and takes away from the enjoyment of the course.
This course was very interesting and engaging.
The lectures are thoroughly enjoyable and interesting.

The strength of this course is definitely that every class introduces you to an interesting new topic in psychology. Paul Bloom is also an amazing lecturer and you'll never be bored in class with his sense of humor and passion for the class. A weakness would be that since this is an overview class, a lot of the material is learned from the readings and it can seem like that in class you are just rushing through it. Though the reading responses can seem short, they end up being a lot more work than you expected.

The course is well designed to move at a good pace so the material was never a problem, but it was difficult to assess how I was doing since we did not get our grades back until well into the semester.

I think the strength of the course was the lectures. I think the class can be improved by making the class not rely so heavily on one kind of exam (multiple choice). More opportunities to show what you know would be appreciated.

I think the class is done phenomenally; the only weakness in my mind is that the exam questions are overly vague, which can make it hard to give the correct answer even if you might know it theoretically.
This has been one of my favourite courses at Yale! Paul Bloom is such a fantastic professor. Very funny and good at teaching through anecdotes etc which really helped me remember harder concepts.

The weakness is that with such a large number of topics its difficult to have an indepth undstanding of many things. However this cost in my opinion is worth the amount of exposure one can get. I also thought the reading being a mix of textbook and news artcles made the readings more dynamic. The reading responses however did not feel valuable.
Really interesting
He goes very fast through the slides so it is hard to take notes
Good introductory survey course; very engaging lectures

The strengths of this course are the professor (Professor Bloom), the outstanding TFs, the guest lecturers (Peter Salovey and Marvin Chun among them), and the organized course content. A weakness of the course is that it gives only one or two lectures for some of the major fields of psychology (including clinical psychology and abnormal psychology), so it truly is an "introduction to psychology" with a moderate but not rigorous level of detail.

I was most fond of professor Bloom's energetic, humorous, and lighthearted approach to the class, but the speed of lecture could be slowed down with more thorough slides; Peter Salovey's lecture style and slides should be used as templates.

Strengths: not many. The course was at least somewhat interesting?

Weaknesses: instructor, TAs, grading, workload. I think the instructor had too many slides for each class and went way too fast through them. You were then forced to go through the slides (which hardly had words on them) to try and fill in the gaps. Further, there was so much reading assigned for the course that it was hard to keep up. In combination with the dense lectures this made it very hard to keep up with the course content in a way that set up you to good on the exams. The exams themselves asked many oddly specific questions that required you to do all of the readings in their entirety. The other part of the grading were reading responses, which were only out of 3 points and NOT curved. This means a 2/3 netted you a 67% for that week. Also, some TAs were more generous than others (mine was not). Overall this made the course stressful.

I loved going to lecture and listening to Paul Bloom, since he really knows his stuff. However, I thought the grading of the reading responses was unfair, as they were graded on a three point scale. If I made even a minor mistake, I got a two (66%). I think it would be better to grade the reading responses on a ten point scale.
The strength of this course is definitely the topics Professor Bloom chooses to cover. I felt like the selection provided a good foundation for students taking an intro to psych course.

The strengths of this class include professor Bloom and his engaging lectures. The weakness of this course is the lack of clarity on what details are fundamental to our understanding and learning. It could be difficult at times to learn the material without knowing what is expected of the students.

The obvious strength of this course is Professor Bloom - you will rarely meet an instructor who keeps such a large lecture engaging. The downside to these engaging and fun lectures is the amount of read you need to do outside of class. There was way too much of it and most of the articles didn't pertain to or build on what was discussed in lecture. I also disliked how heavily based on the reading the exams were - it felt like they were mostly testing irrelevant details from the readings instead of big concepts and experiments from lecture. The reading response prompts could have also been more inspiring and I think the study requirement is a complete waste of time. The lectures made it worth it for me but the rest of the course could really be improved.

I think Professor Bloom is a great lecturer as he included historical examples, videos, specific experiments, and humor into his presentations. Additionally, the work we had to do was not unreasonable and they extended to real world examples of psychological phenomena. I didn't like how the course was graded, especially how the weekly reading responses were out of 3; if one doesn't get a perfect score, they get a 66%. I think if it was out of 5 or something, it would be better.
I loved this course. It was a fascinating overview of psychology and made me want to take more classes in the department.

Strengths are the lectures, but weakness is when the readings and lecture do not overlap for the same material and this could be improved by being more consistent across the two-- that way we know what we have to know.

Strengths of this course are that Paul Bloom is an extraordinarily compelling lecturer-- class time flew by, I looked forward to it every day, and it was as mesmerizing as a great TED talk. One weakness of this course is that the exams (1 midterm and the final) seem to test whether you did the readings by quizzing you on minor details, but not whether you actually understood the overarching concepts. However, the majority of the course-- including the articles, textbook chapters, videos, and reading responses you engage with each week-- is about big ideas. So most of the learning you do for the course doesn't align with the way the exams are designed.

strengths:
- fascinating material
- material that relates to everyday life
- very engaging course
- interesting readings

weaknesses:
- multiple choice exams drive students to learn subject matter by heart

The strengths of the course are the lectures. I always found Professor Bloom's lectures to be very engaging and the material to be interesting, and I also enjoyed listening to the guest lecturers. However, it is difficult to keep up in the class, as we tried to fit in too much content in some of the lectures. The reading responses are also only graded out of 3, despite accounting for 35% of our grade. I thought sometimes my grades on the reading responses weren't quite fair given that one mistake could drop your grade from 100% to 66%. There are only two tests in the class, so for people who did not do well on the midterm, including myself, there was really only opportunity to improve my grade, which was the final.

The strength of this class was definitely Professor Bloom. He is one of the top 3 lecturers I've taken a class with at Yale. He just does an incredible job of teaching while still being a really fun and funny person.

The course is great in that it offers a general, cursory look at all of psychology in just a few weeks. Paul Bloom is a wonderful lecturer, and I enjoyed going to his class. My TA was also very specific in his comments on my reading responses, so the class was pretty well-organized and lectures were incredibly fun to attend. However, the exams are CRAZY specific (like one question will ask about a concept or theory mentioned briefly in a single TED talk or about an idea discussed for 5 minutes in lecture. I wouldn't mind if the exams were particular about details relating directly to psychology, but it felt as though the exams were measuring our ability to memorize the content of all the readings rather than evaluating our ability to rationalize and comprehend psychological phenomena. I would love it if the exams were more general, rather than specific, and I'd love to have more chances to bolster my grade (two exams plus reading responses doesn't leave a whole lot of room for error).
Lecture was great, maybe having a paper could be good
The tests are a lot of memorization not a reflection of what was learned so maybe change that.
I love the lectures but wish the reading responses could be out of 10 instead of out of 3!

The course was a good intro course, but it was very broad and conceptual. I feel like I didn't get as much of a sense of the depth of psychology as I could have gotten. That being said, Paul Bloom is a very good lecturer and I really enjoyed the guest lecturers.

I loved the structure of the class, however, I felt that the exams were kind of unfair--they really tested minute details from the readings, and it didn't really help to study the lectures, and so that kind of messed me up for the first exam

This is a strong course because the professor and guest lecturers were very engaging and kept the info interesting. The workload is also very manageable (although the Saturday deadline for reading responses was strange). Since it is such a big class though, perhaps an optional section could help make it more personal and welcoming?
Interesting lectures and not too much work, good general overview of psychology. It didn't feel super rigorous or challenging, which is both a strength and a weakness.
Amazing lectures. Amazing content. Didnt like that the reading responses were graded out of 3 instead of 10.

My biggest concern for the course was the reading responses. I dont feel as though they were very applicable to the course in terms of their topics and also the grading. The grading did not seem constant across sections and it was graded on a 0-3 scale which was extremely unfair when given a tough TA. Additionally, not all of the readings were very applicable to the course and took a lot of time to read outside class.
I found that the exams were quite difficult in terms of focusing on the small details

Paul Bloom is definitely the greatest strength of this course. While the material itself was super interesting and engaging, Paul Bloom does a phenomenal job of taking it to the next level and presenting it in a way that grabs your attention. I think the only thing that could be improved perhaps is trying to link the different course modules with each other better so that it doesn't seem so much like a random assortment of topics, even though I understand that the course aims to provide a comprehensive introduction to the different areas in psychology.
It seems like there's a lot of writing (approx. 700 words per week), but perhaps they make up for it with the absence of final papers.

The class is super super interesting. Sometimes the readings were extremely long and hard to get through, and sometimes felt a little unnecessary. Also, I don't like how term-dependent a lot of the assessments were. I think that's a big thing in Psych overall, but it was frustrating when I understood a concept but didn't specifically know the exact term. However, I really enjoyed the course and never felt like going to class was a burden. Instead I always looked forward to it.
I think the course was incredibly engaging and very fascinating. I think more review sessions would've helped students do better on the final
The class overall was very good. I do wish we received more guidance on our weekly responses as well as feedback on them when we didn't do well. Exams were extremely challenging, as well.

Professor Bloom is obviously a strength. He was an astounding lecturer. I also really enjoyed the reading responses. I didn't really feel like the exams truly measured what it was we learned, however. The emphasis on rote memorization over content mastery was something I wasn't a large fan of. I don't feel like reading responses alone covered the measurement of content mastery, and would like to see more of that problem solving on exams.

There are a vast number of weaknesses within this course. One of those weaknesses was that a third of a student's grade balanced on a weekly reading response that was subjectively graded on a scale from 0 to 3 out of three (with the percentage being the grade). If a student were to not write exactly what the teaching assistant wanted to see, they would lose at least one point. Following this, the teaching assistant would not give clear reasons as to why they took off the point nor how to improve in the future. I recall that at one time I did not explicitly restate the prompt for the reading response and I was penalized one point for that. The fact that one would lose 33% of their grade because they could not guess exactly what the teaching assistant was expecting is ridiculous. Another flaw with this class is the material that is tested on the exams. The exams would have some questions pertaining to the field of Psychology, but many of the questions were based on specific articles or videos that the professor requested that we read. For example, on the mid term, students were asked what the conclusion of a single Ted Talk video was. Although this seems like a trivial complaint when acknowledged alone, with how much information that we were responsible for knowing, no one was going to consider watching an up to forty minute long Ted Talk video as an important use of time. An individual well versed in the field of psychology, unless they knew the very specific references that the professor chose to use, would not be able to answer many of the questions present on either of the exams. This class was poorly graded and did not inform the students very much about the field of Psychology.

I'm sure it's really hard to teach an intro psych coursethere is such a wide array of material to choose from and so many different perspectives to offer on it all. However, I think Prof. Bloom did a good job of organizing the the lectures in an intuitive way, and I found the material overall really fascinating. He always stuck around to speak with students after class, so the opportunity to interact beyond lectures is definitely there. This year I think was the first time using a new sort of textbook for some of the readings, and although the chapters seemed pretty accessible and easy to comprehend, the information in them didn't seem very tightly integrated into the course.

Paul Bloom and the content of the course are quite engaging. I wish that the reading responses were posted as assignments on canvas and that the prompt was more easily accessible rather than having to dig through lecture slides. I also wish that reading responses were not out of 3 points, as it was a common sentiment among classmates that grading was quite harsh on the responses. The exams were possibly a bit too specific - I wish there was more of an application approach to them rather than rote memorization of a VAST amount of reading material.

The main strengths of this course are that Professor Paul Bloom is brilliant, engaging, and hilarious, and the material itself is fascinating. The amount of assignments and the amount of reading was also very reasonable. I can think of no major weaknesses of the course.

The exams were not as friendly to what we focused on in class as they could have been. Mandatory discussion sections could improve this class so that we would be able to discuss aspects of the readings more in depth and make sure we understand them.

Some students who have previously studied psychology were likely frustrated with how broad this course was.  However, as someone who has never taken psychology, I appreciated the courses introductory nature and now that I have learned the main ideas of psychology, I can choose to study one of these topics more deeply in another course.  All in all, I believe that the broad nature of this course is one of its strengths.  On the other hand, one of the weaknesses is the excessive number of assigned readings.  I found myself strategically choosing which readings to choose because more often than not, the readings were briefly mentioned or were only peripherally relevant (I would mostly skip the news articles as they were typically far too long and would likely be just one question on the exam).  Another weakness was the variance between teaching assistants.  Many TAs were extremely harsh in grading reading responses while others were very lenient.  As result, a good portion of our grade (35%) was dependent on what TA we were assigned.  A possible solution to this would be to standardize the grading of reading responses.
the course gives a very solid foundation to many psychology topics and the tests and assignments do require good knowledge of material

Yes -- I found this course interesting and never felt overwhelmed by the amount of work. I think if I had taken this course earlier in my Yale career, I probably would have decided to take more psychology classes because of it.
yes, great professor
Yes, not a ton of work and very intellectually stimulating

This is a great introduction to psychology. I waited two years to take it with Bloom and I think it was well worth it. Since Chun will probably never teach this again, it might be worth waiting for Paul Bloom to rotate to take it-- his lectures are genuinely outstanding and the workload was very fair.

If you're thinking about studying psychology further then yes. If you just want to understand the basics then do this class BUT with the understanding that it's going to be time-intensive and stressful - think about credit/D'ing this class. Do NOT take this class as an "easy" or fifth course. It is not one. Whoops.

I would recommend taking this if you can take it with Paul Bloom. We learned that we only need to observe a teacher for 5 seconds to know our later evaluations of them, and I stopped shopping all my other "extra" classes after I left his first class. Prof. Bloom is probably the most intelligent person I've ever met yet he is also one of the kindest and most approachable. Don't bother taking it with anyone else.

I imagine many students will be required to take this course, so this question is not especially relevant. That being said, I would definitely recommend taking it with Professor Bloom, who is a very good lecturer and was the best part of the course when I took it.

-if your TA isn't Angela then sure
-Paul Bloom is very funny and well versed in the theories
With Prof Bloom, yes. He's amazing and you'll learn so much that will blow your mind.
YES.  This was an amazingly taught course with very intriguing material.  I never once even thought of skipping lecture.

This class is by no means the gut that some make it out to be. All the readings and lectures must be done in  order to have a chance of passing the exams. Nonetheless, it is a very interesting course that anyone should consider taking
Yes!!!
Professor Bloom is incredibly engaginghis lectures are excellent and make the course worthwhile.
Yes, I would recommend this course. It's not too hard and quite engaging! I think that anyone with even a fleeting interest should take Intro to Psych (especially with Bloom!), even just Credit/D
Absolutely. The lectures and readings were absolutely fascinating.
Wonderful class, the material is very interesting, and I enjoyed all the readings.
Yes definitely! It is a fascinating course that teaches you basic knowledge that everyone should have about psychology. It's one of those classes that you just have to take during your time at Yale.
Yes. Anybody can learn and benefit from intro psyc.
The class is very interesting and you will enjoy coming to lecture every Tuesday and Thursday.
As a student who took intro psych twice, TAKE IT WITH PAUL BLOOM IF YOU CAN. He is the best.

I most definitely recommend this course to any student at Yale, especially if it is taught by Paul Bloom. Amazing, funny lectures, and really interesting materials. If you're going to take this class, you should go to every lecture.
Definitely a good intro class.

YESSSSSSSS. Take this class, even if you aren't interested in social sciences, or more psychology or anything. It is just taught in such an engaging, interesting manner. I never missed a single lecture.

I would highly recommend this course to another student because the basics of psychology are useful to anyone and everyone, whether you will major in it or not. Understanding our brains and the way we think and interact with others is SO important for life.

I definitely would. I didn't enjoy this course quite as much as someone else might just because I don't have a great interest in psychology. For someone that is interested in the topic, this class is wonderful. The professor is hilarious and engaging. The TF's are knowledgeable and willing to help. Definitely a great intro level course.
yes! It is amazing. It is really fun. Not that hard. Lectures are super engaging.
Yes, Paul Bloom was wonderful.
Yes - I think everyone should probably take intro psych or intro cog sci at some point. You'll learn about yourself.
Yes, the lectures were fantastic and the information was very interesting and enlightening.
Yes, I overall enjoyed the class and got a lot out of it.
I would if you need to take a psychology credit. Specifically, Professor Bloom is an amazing lecturer, so definitely take the course with him!
I would strongly recommend this course for any student interest in psychology
Yeah, if you are looking for an introductory lecture with not too much work. The exams are tough, however, so be prepared.
Yes, it was exciting and entertaining.

No. For an "introductory level" course, the insane amount of weekly readings and nitpicky TF gradings on the reading responses is not worth it. The tests are less conceptual and more about remote memorization, which is pretty unfortunate. They throw way too much stuff at you and expect you to sort out the mess on your own. There's just too much information to digest for tests. The exams will quiz you with questions like "what did so-and-so say in [insert title] TEDx talk" rather than simply taking the CONCEPT from the TEDx talk (or articles, etc.) and testing your actual understanding of a certain idea.
Yes-- It is a great course.  I especially enjoyed it because I have not had any psychology experience before this.

Yes! It's a great course which covers exactly what it says that it will.  It is very important to do the readings and to show up to lecture.  Prof. Bloom taught it without a textbook, yet followed a rigorous and clear structure of the course.  The class is not easy, but the material is intuitive and easy to remember.  The class requires concentration and attendance in lecture as the powerpoint slides are very hard to follow without having heard the lecture.  There are often small insights into the material through pop culture (or at least what Prof. Bloom thinks is pop culture) and these would make little to no sense without having seen the lecture first.  It is also very important to do the readings. You will be tested on them and they are a good supplement to the lectures.  I found it boring to do the reading before lecture as the lecture then felt repetitive.  (The readings generally contain much more information than the lectures).  
The lectures overall are stupendous and fun.  The grading is not harsh and is fair to all.  There are weekly reading responses, though these offer little insight into how well one actually understands that material and instead seem to reflect the ability to regurgitate material from the readings.  The tests are cake if you can memorize information and harder if you can't.  They tend to be based on overly simplistic representations of the material and distill lectures into 2 or 3 questions.  But they cover the material evenly and fairly, and they are very similar in style and tone to the practice tests on Canvas.

I would recommend this course to another student if they want to experience extremely interesting lectures and learn about concepts which are often very applicable to every day life. However, I would only recommend this course if the student understands that there is a great deal of work and detail-oriented reading and studying first. The two exams test very detailed information, the reading responses take time, and the experiment portion takes up more time than one would think. But overall, very interesting and mostly fun!
Yes. Take this course to experience the fabulousness of Paul Bloom.

Sure./ If you like psych or need a SO credit its not a bad course. The exams were unfair and the lectures were often a waste of time, but the material was interesting. Honestly the mandatory research participation requirement is unnecessary and was the worst part of the course by far.

I highly recommend taking PSYCH 110 with Paul Bloom. The course was incredible, one of the best I've taken at Yale. The material is very interesting and stunningly well taught. Even though the lecture is large, it feels like a much smaller class. There are a good number of readings but other than these workload is very low and grading is fair. I actually looked forward to going to this class.
I would, however, I would suggest taking it Credit D.
Yes, I would. It provides a very interesting overview of psychology.
Absolutely! My favorite class I've taken at Yale so far (only a first year tho).
Yes, if you are interested in psychology, but don't take the course expecting it to be a gut.

I personally realized after taking this course that i dont really like psychology, but i think the course itself is great and that Professor Bloom is a great professor, so if you have any interest take it!
Yes, I think every first year should take this course. It's a good introductory course and helps you to understand others better
I would highly recommend this course to another student it is really interesting, well-taught, and the workload is manageable.
If you are a potential psych major, take this class.  It will give you a very good understanding of what pursuing a degree in psychology could look like.
Yes. This course is really interesting for people studying all types of different things.
def take this when paul bloom teaches it if you can/if he teaches it again. i had such a more fun time than my friends who took it with other professors in other semesters.
Yes, this is an interesting course with an engaging lecturer.
DEFINITELY! One of the best courses I've taken at Yale so far (rising junior).

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to another student! You don't need to have taken any psychology course in high school in order to do well and understand the material in this course; I never took psychology before this course and I learned so much, but I never really felt like I was at a disadvantage to students who took AP or IB psychology in high school. All of the material is so interesting in this course, and there's never a dull moment in the class! I personally always left class talking to my friends about all of the things that fascinated me from that day's lecture, and that is one of my favorite feelings to have with a course. You also have the opportunity to learn a lot about yourself, others, and society through this course, and you get to see and reflect on why we do the things that we do and how we can change that to make a better society for everyone. This was my favorite course this semester, and I would recommend it to anyone even remotely interested in psychology! It's an amazing experience and I think everyone should take it!
This class is absolutely a must-take Yale class. I took it as a humanities major looking for a fifth class and for large parts of the semester is was certainly my favorite class.
Yes, definitely! I'm so much more excited to take psych courses next semester!
Yes
Yes! Interesting and not too hard
Be prepared to study hard for exams, but absolutely take this class if you're interested in (or even curious about) psychology.

I would recommend this course to a student interested in the psychology major. The course goes very quickly and in broad strokes, so be prepared to only gain a cursory knowledge of the main topics in psychology.
Yes, I was very engaged and learned a lot.
Yes - excellent professor, well-taught course.
Yes
Yes - a wonderful introduction thats continuously engaging. Highly recommend with Bloom!
Yes, this course provides a lot of interesting and relevant material for someone who does not necessarily plan to be a psych major.
Yes, I would recommend this course because it is extremely applicable to daily life and thus to all fields.

This course is an interesting intro level, but I wont be going any further. I found the material a bit unsatisfying and the exams unnecessarily tricky. The weekly reading responses are a great exercise, though, and I did learn a lot writing them.
Yes. I learned a lot, and it was fun materials. There was a lot of work, but if you were willing to try, you can learn a lot.
Yes.

Yes! But I think dependent on the teacher. Paul Bloom is an absolutely fabulous lecturer and I think that the class 100% hinges on the professor. If the professor is subpar, the class would have been miserable.
Yes. Very interesting and fun.
No because the tests dont reflect class
I would recommend the course to another student.  Be wary of the tests--stay on top of the reading.
Yes, certainly with Paul Bloom!

I would definitely recommend it. The instructor makes the lectures interesting and engaging, and is open to student questions after class. The material is also cool because it applies to every day life and personal experience.
Yes! Fascinating
Yes, I would recommend it, especially with Paul Bloom.
This course provides a solid foundation in psychology and is interesting enough that I would recommend to people who don't need to take the course for their majors.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone, even if they are pursuing a career that has nothing to do with psychology.
I would absolutely recommend this class to another student. It was one of my favorites I have taken at Yale and made me very intellectually curious.
I would recommend it even to those who are not pursuing anything in psychology. It is a course that will engage a student in an effortless manner.

I would recommend this to any student. I learned some really fundamental psychological theories and phenomena that have altered the way I interpret my and other peoples actions. The course was also very interesting, and Professor Bloom is a great lecturer and a very funny guy.
Yes a must take course as you expand your mind to courses outside of major.
Yes it was lots of fun.

Absolutely. Paul Bloom is charismatic and intelligent and makes the material approachable and digestible. The lectures are succinct and entertaining. He captivates the lecture hall with humor and easy-to-follow presentations of ideas and concepts. He is a fantastic professor and the best lecturer I've encountered in my life. 

The material itself is all easy to learn if you keep up with the reading and pay attention to the lectures. There are no 'tricky' questions on exams or assignments. If you do the work, you'll succeed. The peers I know who struggled in this class did so because they never did the readings. (The exam directly asks questions pertaining to the readings.)

Overall, the class was engaging and stimulating while very very manageable. Favorite class of the term.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. If you are the token therapist in your group of friends, if you like theorizing human behavior, if you want to know why humans do what they do and are interested in the origins of religion, please take this course. Paul Bloom is also an amazing professor. I am a rising senior now and can say that ithout hesitation that this has been my favorite class are yale so far. You really can't get any better. Take it.
I good introduction to psychology. Professor Bloom is amazing!

Very much so. Professor Bloom is an enthusiastic teacher that takes one through an adventure each and every lecture to arrive at his ultimate conclusion. It is such an interesting journey each and every lecture.
Yes

Yes, I would recommend this course.
