The material is interesting and the lectures are engaging (I was usually able to pay full attention the whole hour and fifteen minutes, which I usually find difficult!). It's a good fairly low-stress class for anyone who thinks they might have an interest in psychology - although it doesn't delve deeply into any particular subject.
Yes! It's a great intro course that is applicable to people of all majors and it's not too time consuming.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The workload is manageable, and the content is interesting, primarily because Professor Bloom is so fantastic. I feel that this is a Yale course that is easily accessible to students no matter their interest, expertise, or major, and I feel like the information gleaned from the course can help to inform how we think about ourselves and others.
Absolutely--I would recommend this to any student at Yale no matter what their major is because it is seriously so incredible.

I would highly recommend the course. I am not majoring in psychology but it's a subject that I have long wanted to learn more about, and I feel that a lot of people would enjoy learning about these things.
Yes, if you really need it for a major requirement.
Good course, if you can take it with Psul Bloom then go for it!
Yes, definitely!
Yes. Professor Bloom is great.

Yes, I would absolutely recommend to another student. The lectures were well-organized, entertaining, and rewarding; I genuinely looked forward to attending them every afternoon. The workload was not excessive and I think the exams were very fair as long as you studied. The course was able to cover an impressive range of subjects in a short time, all of which were fascinating. And you certainly don't have to be considering a major in the social sciences to appreciate the content.
Absolutely. Incredible professor and engaging material.

This is an interesting course that teaches you how to explain your actions through a psychological lens. However, it's not easy-- there's so much reading that is on the exams, and it's a bit overwhelming even for MCDB/premed people who are used to rote memorization. Take Bloom's class if you want a great lecturer but hard exams. The other intro psych professor (Dunham) apparently gives easy exams (with the class avg being at least 10 points higher than the avg on Bloom's exams). But Bloom is so passionate about this material that his passion really rubs off on you and inspires you, and the class is curved with like 40% of the class getting A- and above, which makes up for the hard exams.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I loved this course and thought it was the perfect level of detail and information for an introductory class. I would recommend it to anyone looking for an interesting and enjoyable class regardless of their major.
Yes. Its interesting and informative.

This is definitely not an easy class, even if you decide to take in CR/D. That said, it is a unique Yale experience you don't want to miss out on, especially if you have Paul Bloom as the professor! So definitely take the class, but be aware of the amount of work it can end up being.
Yes I would recommend it!
Only if they need it as a requirement
Yes. The course material is fascinating and lectures are honestly like TED talks.
I will definitely recommend PSYCH 110 to another student. It was life changing.
Yes!!! But take it with Paul Bloom!!
Yes i very much enjoyed the lectures and felt like i walked away having learned a lot. It was intereting and well run class that i think if one has any interest in the subject they should take it
An excellent class, Professor Bloom is amazing, highly recommend!
Yes, he is an incredible lecturer and the workload is doable
Take this class! Especially with Paul Bloom. He's an amazing professor and the classes feel like TED talks. Keep up with the class readings and you'll be good for the tests!
Yes

Yes it is really interesting. It is a lot of information to take in, in one semester but if you have any interest in psychology it is important to get the introductory background (and a requirement for many higher level psych classes). I enjoyed going to class twice a week.

I would highly recommend this class to any student looking for a great course that explores the workings of the mind, the reasons behind human behavior, and the history and major discoveries of psychological research.

This course is great! Paul Bloom is an excellent professor and the TAs are extremely helpful. The topics covered in the course are extremely interesting and have countless applications in the real world.

I would be cautious in recommending PSYC 110 to another student (especially with professor Bloom). The course has a suspiciously high work load (lots of dense readings, oddly specific exams, weekly reading responses ~600 words). I heard a lot of good things about professor Bloom and so I waited to take the course with him. While he is by no means a bad professor, he also isn't that great. His lectures are a bit unstructured and the slides provided hardly have words on them so they're not really helpful. He also does this weird swaying thing during lecture which I found annoying and often glossed over details. Overall this class was just kind of average but also hard. It was an okay choice for premed and SO but be warned ITS NOT A GUT.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I think it is interesting and informative, and a great way to gain a basic understanding of the field of psychology.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Especially if they are not majoring in Psych. This course should be taken by everyone!
I would recommend this course to another student because of how interesting the class concepts are.

I would recommend this course overall just for Paul Bloom's lectures (and the guest lectures) which were a highlight of my week, because the rest of course was average (lengthy readings, nitpicky exams, not so interesting reading responses and 5 hours of PSYC studies).
Absolutely. Whether or not you are interested in pursuing psychology, it is fascinating to learn about how your mind works and is a valuable experience for any student.
Yeah, great professor.
Yes, I would. Professor Bloom is engaging and entertaining. I very much enjoyed his lectures.

Absolutely take this course-- no matter who you are or what you want to study! If you are interested in why humans are the way they are, from relationships to emotions to child development to dreams to morality, you should take this class. Professor Bloom is not only brilliant but also entertaining. The class feels less like a college course and more like a snappy TED talk you feel lucky to attend, full of cool tidbits and ideas that will make you think about yourself in a totally new light. Be prepared to memorize a lot of information for the midterm and final exam, but if you've been keeping up with readings, which are manageable, it's not too bad.
Absolutely. Everyone at Yale should take this course.

I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in the field of psychology; however, the course covers a lot of material and requires you memorize the material for the assessments, so the student should be prepared to do that.
Yes! I think Intro Psych with Paul Bloom is one of those "must-take" Yale classes.

Yes--but with the caveat that the class involves a lot more work than expected. I initially thought the class was be a straightforward introductory course, but the exams were much more detail-oriented than expected. A lot of students will have to take this class, and if you are forced to do so, just make sure to study for the exams WELL in advance and to take details notes over all of the readings and lectures. Even if you're not interested in psychology, the class was still a lot of fun and the intellectual payout was nice--I do feel as though I understand how and why individuals think, behave, or believe in certain ways better now than I did before.
Yes!
Yes, i think it's important to know about these topics.
Yes! Even to non-psych-majors, just because the human mind is something fascinating to learn about and this class never ceases to surprise me.

Take the course if you would like a broad overview of psychology. Paul Bloom is a very good lecturer, and he makes the class engaging. The weekly responses are fine if you stay on top of them, and the midterm and final come directly out of readings and lectures.

I would recommend this course as an introduction to psychology, just as the name suggests. If you have already taken AP Psych, or perhaps Intro Cognitive Science at Yale, then much of the information will be repetitive.
Definitely very engaging and not too much work, fun introduction to psychology. If you've already taken Intro to Cognitive Science, maybe don't take it, because there is a LOT of overlap.
Yes. This course changed my life.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student because it is a great introductory course to psychology. The course is very intense and you learn a lot of information, but it is extremely interesting.
I would recommend this to someone who needs a social science credit or who is looking for an easy introduction to psychology.
I would recommend this course, especially with Paul Bloom as the professor. Found it to be a rather fun course

I would highly highly recommend this course, especially with Paul Bloom. His class is one of those must-haves that completes your Yale experience. The lectures are very engaging (I never once fell asleep in a 1hr 15min lecture) and there will definitely be at least one point in the class when you will want to become a psychologist. And I'm saying that as an applied math major. Definitely take it, even if you're a second semester senior and are just looking for a fun class.

If you're going to take intro psych you should take it with Paul Bloom or Dean Chun (they will entertain you and help you learn the most). The intro course does tend to cover a lot of stuff that the intro cogsci class also covers so if you are interesting in taking that course or are planning on taking it I don't think you need to take intro psych.
Absolutely. It's a fantastic intro to a really great subject, and has something for everyone in it.

Yes, I would totally recommend this course to another student. Like I said, it helps you in everyday life. You understand others and yourself better, and you can use a lot of the knowledge to your advantage. It is also just an extremely interesting course, and like I said I looked forward to going to lecture.
I would, it's a very interesting class that may change your perspective on the world.
Yes, I would also recommend they take it Cr/D/F, so they would not have to worry about the tough exams.
Yes. Professor Bloom's lectures were worth it.

I would never recommend this class to another student. It was poorly managed and graded. The amount of content relative to the field of Psychology that was covered could have been covered in much less than an entire semester.

I would recommend this course to another student! Prof. Bloom is an engaging lecturer and does a nice job of covering a lot of different concepts. The reading responses can be a bit of a hassle, but so long as you don't wait till the last minute they can also be a lot of fun.

I'd definitely recommend that every Yale student take Intro to Psych. Psychology is a really interesting field that is related to so much in life - current events, history, medicine, philosophy, economics, etc. Professor Bloom sets up the course such that even if you have no background in psychology (like myself) you can still very much succeed.
Totally would! Psych is a fascinating area of study, but a class like this is necessary if you want to do more upper level stuff.

I would definitely recommend this course.  Not only was the material truly interesting but Professor Bloom is a fantastic lecturer. I waited to take this course until after he returned to teach because of all the great things I had heard about him (including that he was like a bloomin onion  layered, crispy, and well-seasoned) and I was not disappointed.  He is quite the character and presents the material in a very memorable and humorous way.  In fact, this was the sole course that I was truly excited to go to every week (and my favorite from this semester considering how many things I learned).  All in all, take this course and take it with Professor Bloom!  But be forewarned, it is a large lecture class so you will have to study to do well in it.  He is very detail-oriented when writing his exams so you will need to remember his passing comments, the odd statistic, an obscure theory, etc.  His exams (multiple-choice) are basically fact recall from both his lectures and the readings which sounds easy at first, but everything is fair game.  Also, pray that you get a nice TA because reading response grades are largely based on how nice your TA is.  Other than those few things, this course it truly fantastic, I learned a lot, and I am very glad to have taken.  If you wont take it for the interesting field that is psychology, then take it for Professor Bloom!
yes, there are many concepts that I found very interesting and are applicable to my everyday life
Take it if Bloom is teaching it again.
